aliases: Uplift Master and his wife Shoshamma

major_events: A twelve-year-old girl is married to a widower groom in 1900 Travancore, South India.
The young bride moves to Parambil, her new husband's house, and adapts to a new life with his sister Thankamma and their son JoJo.
The bride experiences loneliness and homesickness while gradually managing the household and bonding with the residents and animals, including the elephant Damodaran.
Marriage is consummated after several years, leading to a deeper connection between the bride and her husband.
The bride's mother is rescued by her husband from mistreatment by her uncle and brought to Parambil.
JoJo drowns in an irrigation ditch, devastating the family.
The bride learns about the family’s hereditary Condition linked to drowning and water fears, unveiling secrets from the past.
The bride becomes pregnant with their daughter Baby Mol, marking a new chapter in her life.
The story shifts to Digby and his mother in Glasgow, revealing harsh social and economic realities and family struggles.
A twelve-year-old girl is married to a widower groom in 1900 Travancore, South India.
The young bride moves to Parambil, her new husband's house, and adapts to a new life with his sister Thankamma and their son JoJo.
The bride experiences loneliness and homesickness while gradually managing the household and bonding with the residents and animals, including the elephant Damodaran.
Marriage is consummated after several years, leading to a deeper connection between the bride and her husband.
The bride's mother is rescued by her husband from mistreatment by her uncle and brought to Parambil.
JoJo drowns in an irrigation ditch, devastating the family.
The bride learns about the family’s hereditary Condition linked to drowning and water fears, unveiling secrets from the past.
The bride becomes pregnant with their daughter Baby Mol, marking a new chapter in her life.
The story shifts to Digby and his mother in Glasgow, revealing harsh social and economic realities and family struggles.
Digby travels from Glasgow to Madras in 1933 for a surgical position in the Indian Medical Service, experiencing cultural shocks and racial caste systems.
Digby begins work at Longmere Hospital under Civil Surgeon Claude Arnold, struggling with early surgical cases.
Matron Honorine Charlton supports Digby, offering guidance and companionship.
Digby meets Indian surgeon Dr. V. V. Ravichandran, who becomes a mentor and colleague.
Digby performs challenging surgeries, including treatment of filarial hydroceles, peptic ulcers, goiters, and gastric cancer, with Ravichandran's assistance.
Digby and Honorine develop a close friendship, sharing concerns about the political and racial tensions of British India.
Digby joins the Anglo-Indian social circle including the Tuttleberry family and experiences community life.
Jeb, Jennifer Tuttleberry's brother and an Olympic hockey hopeful, is a friend of Digby.
Jeb dies tragically during surgery under Claude Arnold, leading to community outrage and suspicions of negligence.
A public letter signed 'Veritas' accuses Claude Arnold of incompetence and nepotism; a commission is promised to investigate.
Political tensions around the 'White Mutiny' and Indian Civil Service reforms are reported in newspapers.
Celeste Arnold, Claude's wife, grows distant and troubled by the scandal surrounding her husband.
Claude Arnold plans to accuse Digby of impropriety with his wife to discredit him during the inquiry.
Celeste Arnold visits Digby secretly, warning him of Claude's plans and beginning an affair.
Digby and Celeste share moments of intimacy and connection, both feeling trapped and isolated in their lives.
Celeste and Digby become lovers and share intimate moments, while facing the threat of Claude Arnold's plan to accuse Digby of impropriety with Celeste.
Digby receives an anonymous letter warning him of Claude Arnold's intent to name him co-respondent in a divorce, escalating tension.
Claude Arnold exhibits declining behavior due to stress and alcohol, leading to a confrontation with Celeste.
Celeste decides to leave Claude and live independently, planning to take refuge at the Theosophical Society with her ayah Janaki.
Digby and Celeste share an emotional and artistic moment, with Digby painting Celeste's body as a metaphor for vulnerability and love.
Digby suffers burns in a fire while trying to save Celeste, leading to physical and emotional devastation.
Big Ammachi copes with the loss of JoJo by engaging in household and garden routines, and confronts supernatural occurrences in the cellar.
Big Ammachi gives birth to Baby Mol and later faces Baby Mol's diagnosis with cretinism, a congenital condition affecting her development.
Rune Orqvist arrives in Cochin and establishes Saint Bridget's Leprosarium, dedicating himself to leprosy patients and receiving support from local patrons including Chandy.
Rune develops a close working relationship with Chandy, who becomes a friend and supporter of the leprosarium.
Big Ammachi supports education for Philipose and Joppan, confronting caste-based discrimination and striving for inclusion.
Philipose struggles with swimming due to a hereditary condition but develops a strong desire for knowledge and learning, aided by Koshy Saar.
Philipose rescues a baby's life from choking in a river during a flooding event, demonstrating courage despite his fear of water.
Rune undergoes a spiritual transformation and decides to retreat to a monastic life after years of medical practice.
Digby being cared for by Lena and Franz Mylin and their driver Cromwell at AllSuch Estates after his injury, contemplating his shattered physical and emotional state.
Celeste and Digby become lovers and share intimate moments, while facing the threat of Claude Arnold's plan to accuse Digby of impropriety with Celeste.
Digby receives an anonymous letter warning him of Claude Arnold's intent to name him co-respondent in a divorce, escalating tension.
Claude Arnold exhibits declining behavior due to stress and alcohol, leading to a confrontation with Celeste.
Celeste decides to leave Claude and live independently, planning to take refuge at the Theosophical Society with her ayah Janaki.
Digby and Celeste share an emotional and artistic moment, with Digby painting Celeste's body as a metaphor for vulnerability and love.
Digby suffers burns in a fire while trying to save Celeste, leading to physical and emotional devastation.
Big Ammachi copes with the loss of JoJo by engaging in household and garden routines, and confronts supernatural occurrences in the cellar.
Big Ammachi gives birth to Baby Mol and later faces Baby Mol's diagnosis with cretinism, a congenital condition affecting her development.
Rune Orqvist arrives in Cochin and establishes Saint Bridget's Leprosarium, dedicating himself to leprosy patients and receiving support from local patrons including Chandy.
Rune develops a close working relationship with Chandy, who becomes a friend and supporter of the leprosarium.
Big Ammachi supports education for Philipose and Joppan, confronting caste-based discrimination and striving for inclusion.
Philipose struggles with swimming due to a hereditary condition but develops a strong desire for knowledge and learning, aided by Koshy Saar.
Philipose rescues a baby's life from choking in a river during a flooding event, demonstrating courage despite his fear of water.
Rune undergoes a spiritual transformation and decides to retreat to a monastic life after years of medical practice.
Digby being cared for by Lena and Franz Mylin and their driver Cromwell at AllSuch Estates after his injury, contemplating his shattered physical and emotional state.
Rune Orqvist performs reconstructive hand surgeries on Digby, using innovative techniques to restore some function.
Digby undergoes rehabilitation through art therapy with Elsie, Chandy's daughter, reconnecting his brain to his injured hand.
Rune dies suddenly of a heart attack at Saint Bridget's, deeply impacting the community and Digby.
Digby assumes a leadership role at Saint Bridget's leprosarium after Rune's death, facing uncertainty about his future.
Philipose saves the boatman's baby at Saint Bridget's leprosarium by assisting in emergency surgery performed under Digby's guidance.
Philipose returns home after recovery, celebrated by family and community for his heroism despite his fears and limitations.
Uplift Master and Shoshamma move to Parambil, initiating social and infrastructural improvements, including forming YMCA and YWCA groups.
Parambil achieves the 'district village' designation after sustained efforts led by Uplift Master, bringing government funds and services like a post office.
Philipose goes to Madras Christian College, facing culture shock, ragging, and challenges with hearing impairment threatening his academic future.
Philipose faces the reality of nerve deafness diagnosed by Dr. Seshaya and audiologist Gurumurthy in Madras, leading to his return to Parambil.
Philipose meets a young woman, Elsie (Chandy's daughter), on the train journey home; they share a connection and artistic sensibilities.
Philipose returns to Parambil amidst fears of a Japanese invasion and increasing wartime hardships, establishing a Feeding Center with Uplift Master to combat famine.
Philipose begins publishing his writing in the Manorama newspaper, gaining local acclaim and stirring controversy with satirical pieces.
Philipose's engagement and subsequent marriage to Elsie are arranged with the involvement of Broker Aniyan and the families; they express mutual respect and artistic support.

The couple establish their home at Parambil, expanding their living space and Elsie's art studio; Elsie gains recognition for her portraits, including that of Lizzi, who later disappears due to her husband's troubles.
Philipose struggles with anxiety and fears related to Madras and social interactions, leading to tensions with Elsie concerning travel and the fate of a beloved plavu tree.
The couple's first child, Baby Ninan, is born prematurely; despite initial struggles, he grows and shows signs of the Condition.
In 1947, India gains independence; Philipose documents the familial and societal impacts amidst ongoing political turmoil.
Elsie gains national recognition for her art, winning a gold medal at a Madras exhibition, with her works gaining critical and commercial success.
Philipose continues to balance his writing and family life, supporting Elsie's career and managing household and community relations.
Following ongoing tensions around Elsie's desire to visit her father's estate, she returns there while pregnant; Philipose remains anxious about such trips.
After the monsoon begins in 1949, Baby Mol performs a monsoon dance securing the rain's loyalty.
Baby Ninan is tragically impaled by a branch of the plavu tree and dies, devastating Philipose and Elsie and leading to the tree's complete removal.
Following Baby Ninan's death, Philipose and Elsie's marriage undergoes strain and blame, with Elsie leaving the household.
In 1950, Digby Kilgour manages the Gwendolyn Gardens estate, handling hazards such as landslides and medical emergencies with assistance from his servant Cromwell.

Digby treats an estate laborer's wife, Lizzi, who arrives with a self-inflicted abdominal wound from an attempted home birth; she reveals troubles with her husband Kora, who has suffered from mental illness due to asthma exacerbation.
Philipose faces the reality of nerve deafness diagnosed by Dr. Seshaya and audiologist Gurumurthy in Madras, leading to his return to Parambil.
Philipose meets a young woman, Elsie (Chandy's daughter), on the train journey home; they share a connection and artistic sensibilities.

Baby Ninan is tragically impaled by a branch of the plavu tree and dies, devastating Philipose and Elsie and leading to the tree's complete removal.
Following Baby Ninan's death, Philipose and Elsie's marriage undergoes strain and blame, with Elsie leaving the household.
In 1950, Digby Kilgour manages the Gwendolyn Gardens estate, handling hazards such as landslides and medical emergencies with assistance from his servant Cromwell.

Digby treats an estate laborer's wife, Lizzi, who arrives with a self-inflicted abdominal wound from an attempted home birth; she reveals troubles with her husband Kora, who has suffered from mental illness due to asthma exacerbation.
Philipose's marriage to Elsie is fractured after Baby Ninan's death; Elsie leaves but returns a year later with their daughter Mariamma following a traumatic birth.
Elsie creates a large stone sculpture called the Stone Woman, which Philipose accidentally damages.
Elsie suffers a complicated breech birth resulting in heavy hemorrhaging; she narrowly survives with the help of Big Ammachi and Anna, a young helper.
Elsie disappears mysteriously, leaving behind her clothes and a drawing for Big Ammachi, who suspects Elsie committed suicide.
Lenin Evermore, Lizzi and Kora's son, survives a smallpox epidemic that kills his family and eventually comes to Parambil to live with Big Ammachi.
Lenin's childhood is marked by misbehavior and visions of becoming a priest; he adapts to life in Parambil with challenges and friendships.
Big Ammachi raises Mariamma, Philipose and Elsie's daughter, who grows resentful of Lenin.
Joppan grapples with his father's legacy and his relationship with Philipose about land and entitlement.
Communist Party influences grow in Kerala, affecting local politics and social attitudes.
The Maramon Convention features a fiery American preacher, Reverend Rory McGillicutty, whose passionate sermons challenge the Malayali Christian audience.
Uplift Master translates McGillicutty's sermons, rallying the crowd to donate generously toward a new hospital for the region.
Big Ammachi eagerly supports the establishment of a hospital at Parambil, inspired by the Maramon Convention and Uplift Master's fundraising efforts.
Mariamma decides to pursue medical school at Alwaye College, influenced by Big Ammachi's encouragement and her own fear of sickness after witnessing the plight of beggars.
Baby Mol suffers a severe health crisis related to her heart and lung issues, requiring treatment at a distant government clinic; she eventually stabilizes but remains fragile.
Podi agrees to marry Joseph, beginning a new chapter away from Parambil, with Joppan's approval and Joseph's ambitions.
Big Ammachi and Baby Mol die peacefully together, leaving a profound void in the household; Philipose mourns deeply.

Mariamma begins medical studies in Madras, adapting to the new environment and facing challenges including harassment by the examiner Dr. Brijmohan Sarkar, whom she physically defends herself against.
Mariamma and Lenin maintain correspondence; Lenin struggles with his faith and ultimately joins the Naxalite movement after witnessing atrocities against tribal people.
Mariamma supports Lenin during a brief visit, but they part with unresolved emotions; Lenin proposes marriage and revolutionary life, which Mariamma rejects.
Mariamma faces pregnancy symptoms but tests negative, causing personal disappointment; she returns home to Parambil, finding some peace and reconnection with family and surroundings.

Philipose visits Cochin and encounters a statue resembling Elsie; during his train journey to Madras, the train crashes into a gorge and he survives, recalling his life and family with renewed purpose.
Big Ammachi eagerly supports the establishment of a hospital at Parambil, inspired by the Maramon Convention and Uplift Master's fundraising efforts.
Mariamma decides to pursue medical school at Alwaye College, influenced by Big Ammachi's encouragement and her own fear of sickness after witnessing the plight of beggars.
Baby Mol suffers a severe health crisis related to her heart and lung issues, requiring treatment at a distant government clinic; she eventually stabilizes but remains fragile.
Podi agrees to marry Joseph, beginning a new chapter away from Parambil, with Joppan's approval and Joseph's ambitions.
Big Ammachi and Baby Mol die peacefully together, leaving a profound void in the household; Philipose mourns deeply.

Mariamma begins medical studies in Madras, adapting to the new environment and facing challenges including harassment by the examiner Dr. Brijmohan Sarkar, whom she physically defends herself against.
Mariamma and Lenin maintain correspondence; Lenin struggles with his faith and ultimately joins the Naxalite movement after witnessing atrocities against tribal people.
Mariamma supports Lenin during a brief visit, but they part with unresolved emotions; Lenin proposes marriage and revolutionary life, which Mariamma rejects.
Mariamma faces pregnancy symptoms but tests negative, causing personal disappointment; she returns home to Parambil, finding some peace and reconnection with family and surroundings.

Philipose visits Cochin and encounters a statue resembling Elsie; during his train journey to Madras, the train crashes into a gorge and he survives, recalling his life and family with renewed purpose.
Mariamma discovers her father's death after a tragic train accident and conducts an autopsy revealing neurofibromatosis causing acoustic neuromas.
Mariamma decides to specialize in neurosurgery inspired by her father's condition and is accepted to the Christian Medical College in Vellore.
Parambil flourishes under Joppan's care; Mariamma struggles with hospital bureaucracy but receives strategic help from Uplift Master.
Mariamma builds a detailed genealogy to track the hereditary Condition affecting her family and others, enlisting Broker Aniyan's help.
Mariamma reconnects with Lenin after his unconscious arrival at Saint Bridget's, performs a life-saving ventricular tap, and arranges brain tumor surgery in Vellore.
Lenin undergoes neurosurgery successfully, post-operative recovery includes emotional reconnection with Mariamma before being taken into police custody.
Mariamma struggles with family secrets revealed through her father's journals, including her true maternal parentage and her mission to understand the Condition.
At Saint Bridget's, Mariamma assists Digby in surgery and confronts complicated feelings about her family history and her unexpected parentage.
Mariamma visits Elsie, her mother and a celebrated artist at Saint Bridget's leprosarium, unveiling hidden family truths.
Big Ammachi eagerly supports the establishment of a hospital at Parambil, inspired by the Maramon Convention and Uplift Master's fundraising efforts.

At Saint Bridget's, Mariamma assists Digby in surgery and confronts complicated feelings about her family history and her unexpected parentage.
Mariamma visits Elsie, her mother and a celebrated artist at Saint Bridget's leprosarium, unveiling hidden family truths.

In 1950 at Gwendolyn Gardens, Digby Kilgour hosts Planters' Week with changing social dynamics post-Independence; he is reunited with Elsie, his former muse and Mariamma's mother, who has suffered great personal tragedy.
Digby helps Elsie rediscover herself through art, especially sculpture, providing emotional support and companionship; Elsie shows signs of leprosy but continues to create.

Elsie decides to visit Parambil due to Baby Mol's illness, revealing she has leprosy which caused her separation from her family; Digby accompanies and cares for her upon return, accepting her disease and their continued love.
Elsie and Digby's relationship deepens despite the hardship; Elsie chooses to live concealed at Saint Bridget’s leprosarium to protect her daughter, Mariamma, from the stigma of leprosy.

In 1977 at Saint Bridget's, Mariamma confronts the reality of her mother's long hidden presence as a leper in the leprosarium, learns about her parents’ sacrifice and endurance, and experiences complex emotions upon meeting her mother.
Digby remains devoted to Elsie, caring for her despite her debilitating disease; together they share a profound bond shaped by love, loss, secrecy and art.
